proposal.title: Council Bounty Management
proposal.description:
The Council have, for a while now, been responsible for managing the community bounties. This has so far not worked perfectly, for a variety of a reasons. Most likely the scope is unclear due to instructions being spread across multiple sources. We have seen what looks like plenty of misunderstandings, from all sides, recently and this needs to be addressed. It goes without saying that Jsgenesis has failed plenty of in dealing with their side of this properly.

In any event, we want to improve the situation, as we believe this not only is trains the Council for getting work done in the future, but also trains the community in using proposals and github.

details.Text:
The intended workflow, from the Councils POV, is:

1. Jsgenesis creates an issue in the [Community Repo](https://github.com/Joystream/community-repo), explaining what the bounties is for, success events and their associated rewards, some restrictions/requirements, and how the final submission should be done and graded by Jsgenesis. This issue is meant for the Council first and foremost, and ideally, the person(s) attempting, or successfully manages, to solve the bounty need not even read this issue.
2. The Council parses the issue, ask questions if need be, fills in the blanks/details, and creates a forum post about the Bounty. This post should cover:
- All the details needed from the issue
- The rules and format that applies, both from the issue, and any other information the Council sees fit to add
- The expected workflow anyone attempting to solve the bounty must go through

3. Update the `bounties-overview` in the Community Repo (table and json)
4. Somewhat depending on the format, but once the community member(s) thinks the bounty is completed, they make their "final" spending proposal, and a (draft) PR to the community repo.
5. Only once this has been reviewed and the spending proposal is approved by the Council, the PR will be made ready for review, and Council Secretary will request a review from Jsgenesis, along with a link to the approved spending proposal.

In many cases, this will be quite a lot of work for the Council, and it may make sense to assign bounty managers/admins to some bounties. This should (of course), be compensated for their role.

Two examples:
- Bounty #10 will mean lots of uploads, meaning lots of review. In the bounty issue, Jsgenesis proposes a format where the Curators and an admin/manager finds a way to relieve some of the pressure on the Council. As this deals with video uploads, the Curators part of the work is already paid for, but the admin is not.
- Bounty #8 is quite labour intensive, and Jsgenesis requests a closed format. This suggests that the Council sets some ground rules (eg. application process, milestones, etc), and a deadline for applications where anyone can request being assigned the bounty for some period of time. Once they have found a strong candidate, that person must deliver within the agreed time, and their submission must be reviewed. Except (perhaps) the initial step, this is most practical to have a single person responsible for.

proposal.title: Bounty - " Articles on Wikipedia"
proposal.description:
My suggestion to create a Wikipedia about Joystream was warmly received (https://testnet.joystream.org/#/proposals/164)
Therefore, I believe that this topic should be promoted further. And now I will offer a variant of how you can implement the Joystream wiki

I see the implementation of the wiki with the participation of the entire Joystream community. And in order to accept as many uastnikovs as possible, you need to make a reward system. That is, a bounty campaign to create a Wiki.
The bounty campaign looks like this:


Description: The topics of the articles will be listed below. On these topics you should write a short post with an indication of the sources.

Topics: 1. History of Joystream
2. Features:
2.1 Video
2.2 Testnet
2.3 Forum
3. Censorship on the site
Note: Posts must be unique! You can't copy the previous person's post and change a couple of sentences. The uniqueness must be at least 60%
Rewards: One best post of each category will be selected, and the user who wrote it will receive rewards in the form of - $ 12 in Joy tokens


As the site develops, it will be possible to supplement existing sections, as well as create new ones.
If you do not like my proposed sections, or want to offer your own-offer.

This bounty should be distributed separately for English and Russian speakers. That is, it will be divided into two full-fledged bounties.

I have provided 6 sections (including subsections), for each article written in the section will pay$12. The amount allocated for these two bounties will be equal to $ 240 or 3404255 in Joy tokens (at the current rate of $0.0000423).

8. Done!

proposal.title: JoystreamStats development (week 7/21)
proposal.description:
This is an update on latest development and a plead to the council for funding.

In the third week of February 2021 the stats website has been upgraded and amended by a backend to cache data and thus reduce the load on the official websocket endpoint. 

From now on clients connect directly to the socket.io endpoint run by joystreamstats.live where chain data is cached in a PostgreSQL database. The frontend uses Typescript flavored React .

The rewrite is nearly finished due to the generous help of freakstatic who wrote the council report generator and contributes code to parse block events and era data. Additionally oiclid offered help to redesign the whole page. Stay tuned!

Currently the most requested feature is the display of historic data for validators to supplement their FM reports. This will be available within hours, just in time for the recently ended scoring period.

If you have feature requests or are interested to join the team, please leave a message on the forum with your tg/discord handle:
https://testnet.joystream.org/#/forum/threads/257

New features:
- redesign the frontpage to show a better overview (#84)
- add a navigation bar to all components (#84)
- add modals for details on members and validators
- add support for channels and existing media
- collect info on amount of spending proposals (#82)
- improved validator overview answering questions listed in (#63)
- new reward chart to show development over time (#84)
- add backend to cache data and reduce burden on the frontend
The results become visible once the new version is released. The currently planned release date is end of February 2021.

All referenced issues can be found here: https://github.com/Joystream/community-repo/issues

proposal.title: Competition 1 - Amendment to rules
proposal.description:
The Joystream Stickers Competition has been quite successful, there have been many more entries than expected. Given to the influx of new users I still haven't found an optimal way of doing the final prize voting process. This was supposed to happen but has been pushed back more than once.
Rather than delay this competition anymore, I suggest using the last $50 for two more submissions ($25 each) with identical terms otherwise. This would allow for two more entries but remove the grand prize.
The original rules agreed on state that the council can amend the rules and conditions at any time if a text proposal is approved.

proposal.title: KPI 12.5: Managing the Working Groups
proposal.description:
With the amount of new uploads on the platform`*`, it's become clear that the Content Curator team needs a more defined scope of work. Especially as it relates to [Bounty #10](https://testnet.joystream.org/#/forum/threads/217), and the [Founding Member](https://www.joystream.org/founding-members) program - both of which incentivizing uploads to the platform.
We have therefore [drafted up some guidelines](https://github.com/Joystream/helpdesk/tree/master/roles/content-curators#working-as-a-curator), that the Council should use as a reference for a `Create high level, yet specific, list of tasks for the Working Groups`, for the Curator Team, and especially the [Curator Lead](https://github.com/Joystream/helpdesk/tree/master/roles/content-curator-lead) as required in KPI 12.5.

`*` We are aware of the issue with the [player](play.joystream.org/) not indexing new, or changes to, videos and channels. It will hopefully be fixed today!

details.Text:
For the Council, this means:
- Read the [guidelines](https://github.com/Joystream/helpdesk/tree/master/roles/content-curators#working-as-a-curator)
- (Propose and) agree to some frequency/deadlines for these reports
- Agree to any changes between the guidelines we drafted, to the actual Council enforced policy
- Agree on the consequences of failure
- Post the policy to the [Community Repo](https://github.com/Joystream/community-repo)
- Communicate them to the Curator Lead, and the Community
- Enforce them (Ref KPI 12.6)

This KPI also requires creating some requirements for the Storage Providers, and especially the Lead as well, but these requirements should be easier for the Council to decide on by themselves.

posts.text:
- There needs to be an incentive for working groups to report back.
- The council should have to re-approve group payments once per term.
- Working group members and especially leads need to make their contact details known to the council.
- The storage working group should provide always up to date status information for all connected nodes (similar to https://status.joystream.org/status).
- The content curator group should give feedback what tools are needed to curate content. Presumably an interface with buttons could be handy.

(I had writted a more but the interface decided to reload.)

proposal.title: JoystreamStats APIv1 (weeks 8+9/21)
proposal.description:
With this proposal i am happy to announce JoystreamStats APIv1 for apps based in the Joystream ecosystem.

It connects to a local node and generates database of resources available on the chain and exposes them at `api.joystreamstats.live`.

The endpoint is load balanced and the cluster will be expanded depending on demand. Details on what resources are available can be found at above location.

There are a lot of open questions raised in bounties and KPI which this database can help to answer. Feel free to reach out of you are interested in data visualization.

This is a great steps towards the (a bit overdue) frontend rework and other ideas like sprocket or alternative viewers.

Please share your ideas in the comments or use this forum thread:
https://joystreamstats.live/forum/threads/257

proposal.title: PR: API examples and Curator tools
proposal.description:
As the Content Curators workload will be impacted by the scope of work examples approved (and discussed) in proposal [182](https://testnet.joystream.org/#/proposals/182), a simple script to get changes made to the Content Directory is made available to them in the PR.
This can of course be improved to automate the reporting process as well.

Further, the [API examples repo](https://github.com/Joystream/joystream-api-examples) is not much seen or used, so it seems to make more sense to move it over to the Community Repo, where it can be maintained and improved (a lot) through the (upcoming) role of `builder`.

details.Text: The pull request can be seen (and reviewed) [here](https://github.com/Joystream/community-repo/pull/120).

proposal.title: Informal Role Hiring: Bounty 10 Admin
proposal.description:
### Opening for informal position:
Bounty #10 Admin (Public Domain Videos)

### Information
* Payment: $22/week (note: this is an initial rate, and may change depending on how many videos require grading. This role may also expand to include more admins eventually. The successful applicant is expected to communicate information about their workload via the forum so that the council can adjust parameters accordingly, without feedback this isn't possible!)

* Duration: Ongoing

* Work: The person doing this position will require some management skills, this will primarily involve keeping track of submissions and managing them as the bounty requires.

* Application thread: https://testnet.joystream.org/#/forum/threads/266

* Bounty thread: https://testnet.joystream.org/#/forum/threads/217

* Submission thread: https://testnet.joystream.org/#/forum/threads/292

* Grading thread: N/A

* Reporting thread: N/A

(continued in Description)

details.Text:
### Work Process
* Reporting requirements: The admin who is selected for this position must produce a weekly report. This should include the `memberId`, `entityId`, grading of each submissions and reward payouts. It should also include a total amount of tokens paid out for this bounty each week.

* Grading process: The admin should base their grading on a variety of factors, including:

	* quality of video/audio

	* quality and accuracy of metadata (thumbnail, descriptions, release year)

	* quality of metadata for the channel (cover, avatar, title)

	* length of content

	* relevance to the platform (videos relating to cryptocurrency could be graded higher than )

(The admin is expected to use these factors to create a simplified grading process that results in an end score that directly translates to a payout (example: A video scoring 7.5/10 would be entitled to a payout of $3.75, whereas a video scored at 10/10 would be entitled to a payout of $5)


1. Users submit videos to the `Submission Thread`

2. Curators need to approve videos and then the admin of this bounty can grade them

3. The admin grades submitted videos in a `Grading thread` (they will need to make this thread)

4. The admin then creates a `spending proposal` to reward graded videos (at up to $5/video and at the current exchange rate). Preferably this is done in a batch to avoid having too many `spending proposals`.


### Application Process
1. If this proposal is approved, a thread will be created for applications (or one may have already been created). Users interested in applying for this position can post an application in the thread. They should give a brief explanation of their skills and any particular special way they would tackle this role.

2. The application thread will be continuously open, but 48h after this proposl is approved, any current council member can create a spending proposal, selecting an applicant and using their account as the payment destination and providing the reasoning for hiring said person.

3. The first approved spending proposal is the person hired for this position.

4. After that point they can create a spending proposal each week for payment.

### Further details
* The Council via approved text proposal can amend or change the responsibilities, payment terms and reporting requirements of this informal position at any time. This includes firing the person if needed.

* If the user is no longer interested in doing the role, they can quit via the forum or proposal. Although not required, it would be good to know the reasoning for someone quitting the role as this helps the council to better develop their systems.

proposer.about: https://joystreamstats.live/members/l1dev

Russian Community Manager
Why not?

posts.text:
This looks like good work, although I'm not a server expert. It seems like it fulfills all the bounty requirements and I've tried it and the performance seems quite good!
The only questions I have at this stage are:

1. The bounty (https://github.com/Joystream/community-repo/issues/101) has $200 available for "up to" two participants, are you applying for this entire reward?

2. What is the storage capacity of the nodes? I ask because depending on storage, these nodes may need upgrading in the future depending on the blockchain size (which seems to be more inconsistent over time, but is still increasing)

3. If you ran this endpoint on a continuous basis, what budget would be required? This could be a separate text proposal and I guess would fall under informal roles. Besides server expenses this would obviously need to include a bit for continued management. The bounty states we have up to $200/month for endpoints without question but the council would need to agree on figures.

author.about: Joystream user. Interested in decentralized projects, governance systems and more user friendly technology.

posts.text:
Good questions!
I understand the bounty in the way that $100 are awarded for the setup and sharing configuration to help others and up to $200 per month. In this proposal I calculated the costs for two terms plus setup fee.

The 10 nodes currently have 50 GB which should be enough for a month. If the chain grows faster than expected expenses may rise. If not $100 monthly should be enough. I plan to add nodes in Russia where a lot of new members are located.

author.about: https://joystreamstats.live/members/l1dev

posts.text:
Maybe someone can help with this:
Using `--rpc-cors all` is not ideal (although it is recommend on https://wiki.polkadot.network/docs/en/maintain-sync) and should just be a temporary workaround. When I used `--rpc-cors 
https://testnet.joystream.org,https://pioneer.joystreamstats,live,https://joystreamstats.live`, the third domain was shown to be blocked. Did anyone try to whitelist more than two domains?

@l1dev voting to approve. My only note is that in the future these kinds of proposals should please include a breakdown of all the costs. In this case the bounty is one thing and the continuous running costs of the server will probably be considered as two distinct things when it comes to the budget. I've begun looking a lot more into what `spending proposals` are reimbursed by Jsgenesis which is why the distinction is a bit important.

@oiclid yes, if this proposal gets fully approved then there is still one more slot available. The second place has a reward of $100 and if agreed on there may be a continued position to run an endpoint.

Hello Everyone! 

I have performed a survey of 281 Joystream Community members according to the questions outlined in the issue #113 (https://github.com/Joystream/community-repo/issues/113).
I also added one re whether or not people view tutorials or read guides in case they didn't read FM rules.

The initial KPI was $200 for at least 100 participants, I believe it's fully met. So, given the current exchange rate (41.57 USD/1MJOY), I'd like to request
(200/41.57)*1 000 000 = 4 811 161 tJOYs

proposal.title: Runtime Upgrade Proposal
proposal.description:
As outlined in [proposal 162](https://testnet.joystream.org/#/proposals/162), we have now prepared a runtime upgrade that makes the following changes:
- Max "active proposal": 5 -> 15
- Proposal parameter changes (eg. the valid limits for proposal parameters):
   - Set Validator Count: `MAX_VALIDATOR_COUNT_MAX` 100 -> 300
   - Set Election Parameters: `CANDIDACY_LIMIT_MIN` 25 -> 50
- Grace period for Runtime Upgrade: 72000 -> 28800

For these three proposals only, `required_stake` increased by 5x.

The reason for lowering the grace period of the Runtime Upgrade is to avoid having to wait so long after they have been approved. We have had to upgrade by "sudo" to avoid both a long, and an unpredictable, waiting period. As with previous runtime upgrades, we are asking not only to approve this change, but also triggering it manually - at noon UTC the day after the proposal is approved.

See this [PR](https://github.com/Joystream/joystream/pull/2209) for full changelog!

posts.text:
For the future it would be great to know how the council can verify the wasm hash and relate it to the code in the PR (or create a runtime upgrade) because in a mainnet scenario the runtime upgrade will come from the community or a technical team and the council needs the ability to review it. In this case the source can be trusted.

On the content:
- the council had approved proposal 140, the PR (https://github.com/Joystream/joystream/pull/2184) did not receive a response. It contained the proposal to raise ideal stake to 30% which has become more relevant recently https://testnet.joystream.org/#/forum/threads/321
- raising the unbonding period does not remedy the noted imbalance (`The uneven distribution may actually make it "better" if users are "forced" in to locking up their tokens for a longer time.`). The main consequence might be that staked tokens can`t be used for voting which makes voting more expensive until v2. Big nominators can still take advantage of low staked nodes.

author.about: https://joystreamstats.live/members/l1dev

posts.text:
- Great point! This can be verified by building the current master branch with docker :)
- We discussed this a bit (both in previous points and internally), and opted against a "half assed" approach. I think you're right in that increasing this particular parameter would be an improvement, but we want to address the whole staking/rewards issue holistically.
- Somewhat in opposition to the above, we decided that re-introducing the possibility of getting slashed outweighs the pros and cons wrt distribution‚Ä¶

@l1dev If you use the google-translate extension, you can see the information here for different providers: https://hostinghub.ru/vps-search

With Russian servers, the situation is usually such that they are more expensive than their world counterparts, but service and support are usually of lower quality.

Of the major providers with international support, at least there are:
https://www.reg.com/
https://ruvds.com/en-rub

Msk.host looks like an interesting option if you are ready to use a translator:
https://msk.host/

proposal.description: As the [previous proposal (203)](https://testnet.joystream.org/#/proposals/203) for this expired, after having gotten 8/12 `Approved` twice (new Council terms resets voting), we're trying again...

proposal.title: Community Repo Banner Competition Prop
proposal.description:
I've come up with a way to turn the Community Repo bounty into a contest which will allow the community to decide the winners rather than the council. The entire process is contained in this PR: https://github.com/Joystream/community-repo/pull/128

Basic process:
1. Users submit entries via PR and a thread on the forums. The first 10 users to submit valid entries get 150k each regardless of competition outcome.
2. The voting process takes place on Discord
3. Three winners are chosen based upon Discord votes and each of them gets a $100 payment (that is the amount this bounty pays out for this contest)
4. One of the three winners may win more (this aspect is handled by Jsgenesis and described in the original GitHub issue).

This `spending proposal` is for 1.5m tokens, which will cover a payment of 150k each to the first 10 users who submit entries to this contest. This payment will go to the address 5GxjmW7qNNh4rTxpcrQgrNEzhdExMF3E6Kj11CogBqUmKYVA. 

The original bounty GitHub issue: https://github.com/Joystream/community-repo/issues/89

posts.text:
I think in order to keep the total budget of 300$ (100$ for three winners) we have to reduce the reward to 80$ for each winner. Then we will have 60$ (approximately 1,500,000 tokens) left to be distributed among all 10 participants.
80$ is still a very good reward for this competition and I think no one will be offended.
I think, while we can single out additional awards from the KPI awards, we should still stick to the agreed budgets whenever possible.

In addition, in the future, for such competitions, I would provide for a condition, based on which there could be not three winners, but two, or even one.
For example, for this competition, get more than 20% of the votes from the total. (Although not sure if it will be possible to implement it when voting in discord)

author.about: Russian Community Manager

posts.text:
@cheomsk I should've clarified that I'll be requesting the 1.5m tokens as part of the budget from Jsgenesis rather than paying for a bounty manager (since I'm going to be the bounty manager for this bounty anyway). This is explained in the new bounties processes and KPIs. I don't know if that request would be granted though, so the tokens can either be taken from the bounty pool or just as spending that isn't reimbursed.

In terms of voting on Discord, since this is the first time we'll be using it for this purpose, the system will be very simple but for sure in future competitions we can look at a more specific set of rules.

proposal.title: Hire for informal role: Bounty 10 Admin
proposal.description:
## Basic Information

Applicant: @stwoof (5CoTKA1x4mox5CKjd4R7AC6sNazbeY5xXv7xDHv47A9jw2w7)

Rate: $22 / week

As was agreed by the council here: https://testnet.joystream.org/#/proposals/191

The application is here: https://testnet.joystream.org/#/forum/threads/266?page=2&replyIdx=12

The applicant completed a test here: https://testnet.joystream.org/#/forum/threads/266?page=2&replyIdx=18

## Additional Requirements

The applicant, if hired by this proposal needs to do the following:

- Create a thread for grading submitted videos

- Create a new separate account for filling with tokens from `spending proposals`

- Create periodic `spending proposals` and pay out users who have submitted videos and have been graded. They also need to keep track of how much is paid out.

- Report / grade twice per week. This should include the date that payments are made, so that the council can keep track of how much the rewards for this bounty pays out to users.

- Create a `spending proposal` once a week for their payments ($22/week)

## Further Details

The Council via approved text proposal can amend or change the responsibilities, payment terms and reporting requirements of this informal position at any time. This includes firing the person if needed.

If the user is no longer interested in doing the role, they can quit via the forum or proposal. Although not required, it would be good to know the reasoning for someone quitting the role as this helps the council to better develop their systems.

proposal.title: media.joystreamstats.live
proposal.description:
For the release of `media.joystreamstats.live` i would like to ask for some tokens in exchange for development time.

This service lists all videos uploaded to the Joystream platform, allows to filter by channel, previews the video, offers it for download and lets the user select any of the available storage providers. All entities are mirrored on the back end and are sent in compact form (JSON) to the front end which is much faster than querying the chain directly.

Do you have experience with bootstrap and how to produce pretty websites? I am happy to shift over some tokens.
Bugs sightings, questions, ideas welcome!

proposal.title: Russia based storage provider
proposal.description:
There have been a lot of newcomers from east Europe and Russia. Our current storage providers are all located in Germany. This new provider increases location diversity and adds 4 TB of storage.

In case the council approves I would like to ask the storage lead to create an opening for the new storage provider created for our many new users located in Russia: `ru.joystreamstats.live/storage`

The IPFS storage was created according to the [storage role guide](https://github.com/Joystream/helpdesk/tree/master/roles/storage-providers), due to lack of a role key with the `--anonymous` flag and can be tested with `media.joystreamstats.live`.

details.Text:
# Specs

According to the provider the server is located in St. Petersburg and has following hardware:
- 16 CPU a 2.1 GHz (Intel(R) Xeon(R))
- 24 GB RAM
- 4 x 1 TB  HDD
- Network: 1 Gigabit, limit: 5 TB / month
